full_text:
Finally, though we have not pushed visualizations to the site, volunteers are beginning to work with the data like Willem Botha's quick dashboard:
https://t.co/EHILxp7zXK

We also made our tips and tricks for reading *your* state's data available. This is the document our data entry people use to track the evolving way that states are reporting their testing. 
https://t.co/QzMjFfsytQ

On the site, we provide more information about our team, including this list of volunteers. They are a rugged, dedicated, inspiring group and @hackingdata, @yayitsrob, and me (@alexismadrigal) are so grateful to them. https://t.co/r9YfXYkwMo

We also have a new website up: https://t.co/PZrmH4bl5Y. 

It's plain and fast. As @kissane, one of our hero volunteers put it: "Today we make it work. Tomorrow we make it look pretty."
@nataleedesotell For sure! As @kissane put it: it's all edge cases
@FearIsNotPanic That's what we've been using in other reporting. I consider it a rule of thumb only. -@alexismadrigal
@nataleedesotell @ICPH_homeless You probably don't want to compute positive %s for all the states because we don't have data for all of them
We await updates from Massachusetts and California, which will also have large numbers. Colorado's numbers are also climbing, standing at 28 cases as of their last update.

We are tracking the number of people who have been tested here, which is different from "number of tests," which is what the CDC has released so far.  

Washington has tested the most people and has the most cases (267). NY now second for cases at 216.

Here's our daily update for 3/11: we have tracked 7,617 cumulative people tested here in the US by tallying individual state reporting. That's up from 4,889 yesterday.

NOTE: We cannot capture all negative tests because not all states report them. 

https://t.co/BS0es79Hew
We've made a Twitter list of state (and DC!) public health departments in the United States. Follow these accounts to stay current on #COVID19: https://t.co/7JrYmLr67l
@AltonMann @CDCgov @PublicHealthPod We're not sure, but from the outside, that is an *extremely* difficult set of data to maintain. -@alexismadrigal
@wcsek @alexismadrigal @PAHealthDept In Pennsylvania, yes. -@alexismadrigal
@GaDPH We noticed that you pulled down your case data. Is this in preparation for a broader update? Or is this an ongoing change?

Something like this chart, from the Italian government, is what we'd like to see from the @CDCgov for state-level data.

(Source: https://t.co/gGpYiwsgM6) https://t.co/sSuMoJmQ75
@sciwriter We'd like to. The way we're running Google Sheets we can't do it. But we're working on it.
@ajdlinux That lower bound is *people tested* — just FWIW -@alexismadrigal
@TychoTithonus @GlobalBioD We’re extremely happy about it, whether or not our document helped nudge them. @alexismadrigal
@adamwulf We’re largely following the state heath departments, though we have enriched with media reports, and probably will do so with TX if the state continues to update slowly. -@alexismadrigal

The @nytimes has a deeply reported story that helps (partially) explain why the number of tests that have been run in the US is so low.
https://t.co/lHdDUAbm0F
@ChrisLKellerABQ Yup. Not difficult: actually impossible. -@alexismadrigal
@ClimateKids2 @daniel_sierra81 Yes, be very careful with doing those quick percentages. They are definitely misleading because of the state of the data. -@alexismadrigal
@jonathangcohen @alexismadrigal @kissane We're working on all the presentation stuff as we speak -@alexismadrigal

The troubling thing is that the true number is probably not much higher, at least not yet. Consider that the province Ontario, Canada has tested 2,747 people alone. 

https://t.co/4p9gdyPHED https://t.co/6f1NTuCuuD

Note: we cannot capture all negative or pending tests because of the way that states report. Consider our number a lower bound. 

See this thread: https://t.co/ig8ZbI9p7b

full_text: If you'd like to write some code to help us keep track of US testing capacity, please open an issue on GitHub and let us know how you'd like to contribute!

https://t.co/sEdYdDSYlw is developed by https://t.co/HceoUNh77B.

This project uses Ruby to crawl state websites and update data regularly at https://t.co/LyiqpeGlMi.

We compare our manually curated data to this data to be sure our numbers look right.

https://t.co/wZ4vfDqDBs is developed by https://t.co/QOLflx2jF3.

This project uses https://t.co/sC5vtHlXFv to expose our data as JSON over HTTP. If you'd like to include our data in your visualization, take a look at this project!

https://t.co/zh8KcvXjVX is developed by https://t.co/ZPMyIrIUOs, https://t.co/3hWYppObr0, and https://t.co/2DatA20Nhm.

This project uses https://t.co/mfjuMyaocH to notify us when a state publishes new numbers.

Currently our spreadsheet at https://t.co/Nj3FiDRkJM is maintained by a team of volunteers organized by @alexismadrigal and @kissane.

Several software developers have contributed to our work as well; we would like to thank them here!

@LorenFFile The more people you test, the more mild cases you pick up. The South Koreans have done a lot of testing. Most experts expect the mortality rate to come down, generally, but there’s still a lot we don’t know. -@alexismadrigal
In the meantime, here's a new FAQ explaining what we're doing: https://t.co/vaxpbm5qyz
@kona404 I’ll check. If this is something we can/must do for a long while, I’m guessing yes. -@alexismadrigal
@The_Garan @alexismadrigal Turns out that was my mistake. Too long at the keyboard today. Will repost tomorrow. -@alexismadrigal
@The_Garan Uhhhh huh ... we’ll look into that. It’s just a google doc. -@alexismadrigal
@ChristineRuana @alexismadrigal We're trying! Without the ability to compel the states to share information (like the CDC could) — we're doing our best to fill in the information. -@alexismadrigal
@ockinger This seems like a sound conclusion to me and one of the reasons we undertook this project. -@alexismadrigal
@The_Garan @joshtpm That's good feedback. Thanks.

We should have a rudimentary website and more sustainable process going in the next day or so thanks to dozens of volunteers. We've hit pause on adding new people to the effort, but we will start bringing more in as we smooth the workflows and have easier ways to plug in.
